title: Official tool alerts savers when 'advisers' are fraudsters
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Sep 4, 2015, 19:07 BST - UK Markets closed Official tool alerts savers when 'advisers' are fraudsters By Katie Morley | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 114.00 -3.00 
For the first time savers will be able to search firms' details to see if they're bonafide or fake 
Savers are to be given access to a new online tool to help them identify whether financial advisers are authorised or fraudulent. 
The new register, which is being built by City watchdogs, will allow people to search for a firm, individual or collective investment scheme by typing in its name, reference number or postcode. 
Every year hundreds of thousands of savers are approached by unscrupulous firms who invest their money in unregulated investments with rip-off charges. In some cases, savers' money is never invested and fraudsters simply run off with it. 
The launch of the tool follows a deluge of warnings from consumer bodies over investment fraud, with one report warning that conmen are fleecing people out of nearly £3m a month in London alone, through a range of sophisticated investment scams. Another report claimed some pensioners are fielding as many as six cold-calls a day from firms. 
Over 55s are considered the highest risk candidates for investment fraud as they are now able to access up to 100pc of their retirement funds in one go. 
The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) already has a register of authorised advisers, but it is cumbersome to use, and does not warn people if firms or individuals are known to be linked to a scam. 
The regulator has designed the new tool to be easier to use to encourage more savers to check up on firms before handing over money to invest. 
YouGov (LSE: YOU.L - news ) data collected in August shows less than half (48pc) of people who have taken financial advice did anything to ensure the adviser was properly authorised. 
Carlton Hood, a director at Old Mutual Wealth, said: “Authorised financial advisers are subject to stringent regulation from the Financial Conduct Authority. Unfortunately, a small handful of fraudsters claiming to give advice are taking advantage of vulnerable customers and putting people off taking advice altogether. 
“Customers can give themselves peace of mind by checking the new FCA register to be sure that they are dealing with a properly regulated financial adviser. This will help them avoid making irrevocable, catastrophic decisions with their finances." 
The FCA is launching the new version of the tool, called the Financial Services Register, on September 7. 
katie.morley@telegraph.co.uk
